title: What will be a decent alternative to fully electric cars when they ban the sale of petrol, diesel and hybrid cars in 2035? - Quora

response.answer_text: There probably won’t be, Toyota has been banging the hydrogen fuel cell idea for ages, but it’s probably not going to be a mainstream alternative. I don’t really expect a blanket ban by 2035, that’s only 15 years away, and the infrastructure for electric cars just isn’t there yet, for all needs. I think there will be lots of exceptions, ifs, buts, etc. Farmers etc. in their big diesels, towing big trailers, in 15 years, will there be a suitable electric alternative at a non-crazy price? I don’t know. My next house purchase may well run primarily on solar, so the idea of an electric car is very, very appealing, but the reality for a lot of people is that rural infrastructure doesn’t exist, the range isn’t there, and the types of vehicle they need doesn’t exist in electric form. I’d be really surprised if the 2035 ban isn’t pushed back to 2040, then maybe 2045, and then lots of exceptions you can apply for. I think once you get 90% of diesel/petrol vehicles off the road, going after the last 10% is true virtue signalling, it’s a lot of effort and inconvenience to people to make absolutely no consequential difference. Far better off taking *one* cruise ship off the high seas, it’ll make *far* more difference in terms of carbon emissions.

There are horses and carts, bicycles and charcoal burners but they are hardly practical. Probably the only thing left would be an attempt to run engines on straight alcohol, and electric on fuel cells, or walk. I can see a big market in moving walkways and replanned boxlike cities with high rise and automated delivery systems.
There isn't a decent alternative now. If you can afford a new car, you just can't get better than an electric one. I can't see alternatives being developed by 2035.
